content.description: Crux is right by the 2nd and 3rd clips on the super thin section.  This route is super well protected but not near as good as Cocopuss.
content.protection: 7 Bolts to the fixed anchors up top!
content.location: This route is located 5 feet right of Cocopuss and just looking for a thin start with one obvious hole in the wall next to the 2nd clip.

content.description: A really enjoyable new line somehow overlooked for many years til now. Follows an engaging line of features up perfect varnish with several reachy moves to a mellow, featured slab finish. A pretty classic set of moves in my book. This route was bolted ground up without hooks with no toprope previewing and no chalk. One of our party was putting in his first bolts on lead up there on a 5.11-not too shabby! We spotted this line while replacing the outdated open shuts on the neighboring routes with mussies and stainless bolts courtesy the ASCA.
content.protection: All stainless bolts and hardware. Fixe rings up top for rappel.
content.location: Between the two established 5.10s following seams and huecos up to the beautiful varnished panel and above.

content.description: This route has a couple good moves but is lacking a distinct crux.  Pro is somewhat mossy so be careful.  This route is worth doing once while in the area getting the other routes ticked off.  NOTICE:  This route and Fontanar's descriptions and length in the Brock/McMillan guidebood are off; routes are at around 180 feet in length!
content.protection: Trad rack only with more of the small to medium sized wires and cams.  Be a little careful; the varnished crack down low is a little mossy; make sure your placements are good.  Up high, there is some friable rock so climb softly.  No anchors; just walk off like you would on Fontanar de Rojo.
content.location: This route shares the same start as Fontanar; but after about 15 feet on the pillar; traverse right on big holds to the obvious thin crack.  Follow this crack up to the chimney; climb through the chimney and up the face to build your anchor.

climbs.name: Moon Where the Wind Blows
climbs.fa: Jonathan K. O'Brien, Dustin V. Yager

content.protection: Well-protected sport climb   8 protection bolts to a chain anchor, 10 draws total.  65' in height.

content.description: This is simply a top rope inside the obvious chimney climbing on the west face.  You can use the Cocopuss anchors to set up your top rope.
content.protection: No Protection; just set up toprope after climbing Cocopuss.
content.location: This route is on the far left side of Coco Crag and inside the obvious chimney.

content.description: This route follows different crack systems to the top of the cliff.  Ascend the right facing flake to the top of the pillar; then follow the obvious varnished corner (crux??) to its top; and then follow the left angling wide flare to the top (some thin gear).  Crux would be the obvious varnished corner; but it looks more intimidating then it is; the jams are SUPER secure.  The crux is great (2 Stars) while the rest would only be 1 star.
content.protection: Bring a selection of gear including some thin crack pieces for the start and also the top.  No anchors so walk off right or left.
content.location: This route is 15 feet to the right of Stupid Cat at the obvious pillar feature.  At the top, I recommend walking off as per Classic Corner of Calico since you'll be right on top of it.

content.description: This is an EXCELLENT sport route on the left side of the Coco Crag about 3 feet right of the obvious chimney.  Varied movements; great protection; and climbing that is much steeper than it appears from the ground; as good as any sport route in Red Rocks at the grade IMHO.  Brock guidebook says 10b but it might be 10a'ish??
content.protection: 8 Bolts lead to some anchors on the slab above.  The route is well protected and climbs great.
content.location: This is the first obvious bolted line just right of the chimney.  Rappel from the anchors with one 60 meter rope; a 50 might make it too??

content.description: Right of Stupid Cat and left of Fontare De Roja. Traverse left from the boulder on good pockets with smeary feet, then climb the crack to the shared alcove, and finally up the face to an anchor (2 bolts).
content.protection: Single rack to BD #1, several slings, 2 quickdraws. A 60m rope will reach for the rappel.Â

content.description: This generally shady area has two EXCELLENT sport routes and two (o.k.) Trad routes.  Worth a visit to climb them all in a day!!  The route lenghts in the Brock/McMillan book for the two trad routes are VERY incorrect and will require walk offs that are pretty easy.
